this study proposes a novel methodology to analyze citywide , discrete urban space using highly accurate anonymized telecom data and machine learning algorithms .
through superposition of human dynamic and urban feature , this work aims to expose clear correlation between the design of the city and the behavioral pattern of its user .

geolocated telecom data , obtained for the state of Andorra , were initially analyzed to identify “ stay-point ” —event in which cellular device remain within a certain roaming distance for a given length of time .
these stay-point were then further analyzed to find cluster of activity characterized in term of their size , persistence , and diversity .

multivariate linear regression model were used to identify association between the formation of these cluster and various urban feature such as urban morphology or land-use within a 25–50 meter resolution .

some of the urban feature that were found to be highly related to the creation of large , diverse and long-lasting cluster were the presence of service and entertainment amenity , natural water feature , and the betweenness centrality of the road network ; other , such as educational and park amenity were shown to have a negative impact .

ultimately , this study suggests a “ reversed urbanism ” methodology : an evidence-based approach to urban design , planning , and decision making , in which human behavioral pattern are instilled as a foundational design tool for inferring the success rate of highly performative urban Place .
analyzing Objective and Subjective Data in Social Sciences : Implication for Smart Cities .
the ease of deployment of digital technology and the Internet of Things gives us the opportunity to carry out large-scale social study and to collect vast amount of data from our city .
in this paper , we investigate a novel way of analyzing data from social science study by employing machine learning and data science technique .
this enables us to maximize the insight gained from this type of study by fusing both objective ( sensor information ) and subjective data ( direct input from the user ) .
the pilot study is concerned with better understanding the interaction between citizen and urban green space .
a field experiment was carried out in Sheffield , U.K. , involving 1870 participant for two different time period ( 7 and 30 day ) .
with the help of a smartphone app , both objective and subjective data were collected .
location tracking was recorded as people entered any of the publicly accessible green space .
this was complemented by textual and photographic information that user could insert spontaneously or when prompted ( when entering a green space ) .
by employing data science and machine learning technique , we identify the main feature observed by the citizen through both text and image .
furthermore , we analyze the time spent by people in park as well as the top interaction area .

this paper allows us to gain an overview of certain pattern and the behavior of the citizen within their surrounding and it proves the capability of integrating technology into large-scale social study .
social media data analysis in urban e-planning .
computational social media data analysis ( SMDA ) is opening up new possibility for participatory urban planning .
the aim of this study is to analyse what kind of computational method can be used to analyse social media data to inform urban planning .

a descriptive literature review of recent case study article reveal that in this context SMDA has been applied mainly to location based social media data , such as geo-tagged Tweet , photographs and check-in data .
there were only a few study concerning the use of non-place-based data .
based on this review SMDA can provide planner with local knowledge about people 's opinion , experience , feeling , behaviour , and about the city structure .
however , integration of this knowledge in planning and decision-making has not been completely successful in any of the case .
by way of a conclusion , a planning-led categorization of the SMDA method 's tool and analysis result is suggested .
modelling urban-scale occupant behaviour , mobility , and energy in building : A survey .
the proliferation of urban sensing , IoT , and big data in city provides unprecedented opportunity for a deeper understanding of occupant behaviour and energy usage pattern at the urban scale .

this enables data-driven building and energy model to capture the urban dynamic , specifically the intrinsic occupant and energy use behavioural profile that are not usually considered in traditional model .
although there are related review , none investigated urban data for use in modelling occupant behaviour and energy use at multiple scale , from building to neighbourhood to city .
this survey paper aims to fill this gap by providing a critical summary and analysis of the work reported in the literature .

we present the different source of occupant-centric urban data that are useful for data-driven modelling and categorise the range of application and recent data-driven modelling technique for urban behaviour and energy modelling , along with the traditional stochastic and simulation-based approach .
finally , we present a set of recommendation for future direction in data-driven modelling of occupant behaviour and energy in building at the urban scale .
automated classification of social network message into Smart Cities dimension .
a Smart City can be defined as a high-tech city with several public and private service capable to strategically solve ( or mitigate ) problem normally generated by rapid urbanization .
different model of indicator have been developed to follow city ’ evolution to become a Smart City .
an example of such model is the standard 37120 from the International Organization for Standardization ( ISO ) that proposes a set of dimension and indicator ( e.g .
transportation , Recreation , Solid Waste ) for service and quality of life for sustainable city and community .

it has been common to find official social network profile of organization and governmental entity related to the service they provide or are responsible for ( water , waste , transportation , cultural event , etc . )
and that are used by citizen as a gateway to directly interact and communicate their complain and problem about those service .

the present paper proposes to apply machine learning algorithms over the urban data generated by social network in order to create classifier to automatically categorize citizen message according to the different city service dimension .
for that , two distinct text dataset in Portuguese were collected from two social network : Twitter ( 1,950 tweet ) and Colab.re ( 65,066 post ) .
the texts were mapped according to the different ISO 37120 category , preprocessed and mined through the use of 8 algorithm implemented in Scikit-Learn .

initial result pointed out the feasibility of the proposal with model achieving average F1-measure around 55 % for F1-macro and 78 % for F1-micro when using Linear Vector Classification , Logistic Regression , Decision Tree and Complement Naive Bayes .

however , as the dataset were highly unbalanced , the performance of the model vary significantly for each ISO category , with the best result occurring for Wastewater , Water & Sanitation , Energy and Transportation .

the classifier generated here can be integrated on a number of different city service and system such as : governmental support decision system , customer complain system , community dashboard , police office , transportation 's companie , cultural producer , environmental agency , and recycler ’ companie .
a business zone recommender system based on facebook and urban planning data .
we present ZoneRec-a zone recommendation system for physical business in an urban city , which uses both public business data from Facebook and urban planning data .
the system consists of machine learning algorithms that take in a business ’ metadata and outputs a list of recommended zone to establish the business in .
we evaluate our system using data of food business in Singapore and assess the contribution of different feature group to the recommendation quality .
automatic sound recognition of urban environment event .
the audio analysis of speaker ’ s surrounding has been a first step for several processing system that enable speaker ’ s mobility though his daily life .
these algorithm usually operate in a short-time analysis decomposing the incoming event in time and frequency domain .
in this paper , an automatic sound recognizer is studied , which investigates audio event of interest from urban environment .

our experiment were conducted using a close set of audio event from which well known and commonly used audio descriptor were extracted and model were training using powerful machine learning algorithm .
the best urban sound recognition performance was achieved by SVMs with accuracy equal to approximately 93 % .
kadaster knowledge graph : Beyond the fifth star of open data .
after more than a decade , the supply-driven approach to publishing public ( open ) data has resulted in an ever-growing number of data silo .
hundred of thousand of dataset have been catalogued and can be accessed at data portal at different administrative level .
however , usually , user do not think in term of dataset when they search for information .
instead , they are interested in information that is most likely scattered across several dataset .

in the world of proprietary incompany data , organization invest heavily in connecting data in knowledge graphs and/or store data in data lake with the intention of having an integrated view of the data for analysis .

with the rise of machine learning , it is a common belief that government can improve their service , for example , by allowing citizen to get answer related to government information from virtual assistant like Alexa or Siri .
to provide high-quality answer , these system need to be fed with knowledge graphs .
in this paper , we share our experience of constructing and using the first open government knowledge graph in the Netherlands .

based on the developed demonstrator , we elaborate on the value of having such a graph and demonstrate its use in the context of improved data browsing , multicriteria analysis for urban planning , and the development of location-aware chat bot .
positive deviance , big data , and development : A systematic literature review .

positive deviance is a growing approach in international development that identifie those within a population who are outperforming their peer in some way , eg , children in low-income family who are well nourished when those around them are not .
analysing and then disseminating the behaviours and other factor underpinning positive deviance are demonstrably effective in delivering development result .
however , positive deviance faces a number of challenge that are restricting its diffusion .
in this paper , using a systematic literature review , we analyse the current state of positive deviance and the potential for big data to address the challenge facing positive deviance .

from this , we evaluate the promise of “ big data-based positive deviance ” : This would analyse typical source of big data in developing countries—mobile phone record , social media , remote sensing data , etc—to identify both positive deviant and the factor underpinning their superior performance .

while big data can not solve all the challenge facing positive deviance as a development tool , they could reduce time , cost , and effort ; identify positive deviant in new or better way ; and enable positive deviance to break out of its current preoccupation with public health into domain such as agriculture , education , and urban planning .
in turn , positive deviance could provide a new and systematic basis for extracting real-world development impact from big data .
why do people move ?
enhancing human mobility prediction using local function based on public record and SNS data .
the quality of life for people in urban region can be improved by predicting urban human mobility and adjusting urban planning accordingly .

in this study , we compared several possible variable to verify whether a gravity model ( a human mobility prediction model borrowed from Newtonian mechanic ) worked as well in inner-city region as it did in intra-city region .
we reviewed the resident population , the number of employee , and the number of SNS post as variable for generating mass value for an urban traffic gravity model .
we also compared the straight-line distance , travel distance , and the impact of time as possible distance value .
we defined the function of urban region on the basis of public record and SNS data to reflect the diverse social factor in urban region .
in this process , we conducted a dimension reduction method for the public record data and used a machine learning-based clustering algorithm for the SNS data .
in doing so , we found that functional distance could be defined as the Euclidean distance between social function vector in urban region .
finally , we examined whether the functional distance was a variable that had a significant impact on urban human mobility .

this is an open access article distributed under the term of the Creative Commons Attribution License , which permits unrestricted use , distribution , and reproduction in any medium , provided the original author and source are credited .
game-based crowdsourcing to support collaborative customization of the definition of sustainability .
successful adoption and management of sustainable urban system hinge on the community embracing these system .
capturing citizen ’ idea , view , and assessment of the built environment will be essential to this goal .
in collaborative city planning , these are qualified and valued form of partial knowledge that should be collectively used to shape the decision making process of urban planning .
among other tool , social media and online social network analytic can provide mean to capture element of such a distributed knowledge .

while a structured definition of sustainability ( normally dictated in a top-down fashion ) may not sufficiently respond well to the pluralist nature of such knowledge acquisition ; dealing with the unstructured community input , assessment and contribution on social media can be confusing .
we can detect fully relevant topics/idea in community discussion ; but they typically suffer from lack of coherence .
in this paper , we advocate the use of a semi-structured approach for capturing , analyzing , and interpreting citizen ’ input .
public official and professional can develop the main element ( topical aspect ) of sustainability , which can act as the skeleton of a taxonomy .

it is however , the community inputs/ideas ( in our case collected via social media and parsed ) , that can shape-up that skeleton and augment those topical aspect with adding the required semantic depth .
in more specific term , we collected tweet for four urban infrastructure mega-project in North America .
then we used a game-with-a-purpose to crowdsource the identification of topic for a training set of tweet .
this was then used to train machine learning algorithm to cluster the rest of collected tweet .
we studied the semantic ( finding the topic ) of tweet as well as their sentiment ( in term of being opposing or supportive of a project ) .
our classification tested different decision tree with different topic hierarchy .
we considered/extracted eight different linguistic feature in studying content of a tweet .
finally , we examined the accuracy of three algorithm in classifying tweet according to the sequence in the tree , and based on the extracted feature .
these are : K-nearest neighbor , Naïve Bayes classifier and Support Vector Machines ( SVM ) .
respective to our data set , SVM outperformed other algorithms .
semantic analysis was insensitive to the depth/number of linguistic feature considered .
in contrast , sentiment analysis was enhanced when part of speech ( PoS ) was tracked .

interestingly , our work shows that considering the topic ( semantic ) of a tweet helped enhance the accuracy of sentiment analysis : including topical class as a feature in conducting sentiment analysis result in higher accuracy .
this could be used as mean to detect the evolution of community opinion : that topic-based social network are evolving within the community tweeting about urban project .
it could also be used to identify the topic of top priority to the community or the one that have the widest spread of view .
in our case , these were mainly the impact of the design and engineering feature on social issue .
the big picture of city : Analysing Flickr photos of 222 city worldwide .
the purpose of the current research is to introduce a new method involving machine learning that can identify and analyse the city image dimension ( CIDs ) of city worldwide .

unlike traditional method , this new method can rapidly identify city image dimension from large set of user-generated photo in an efficient and scalable manner , which could help city manager more effectively plan city branding strategy and city development policy .

label detection with Google Cloud Vision and dimension identification ( or topic extraction ) with latent Dirichlet allocation ( LDA ) modelling were used to analyse 222,000 photo of 222 city worldwide from Flickr.com .
theoretically , this study reinforces the existing literature using Big Data , present alternative way to identify CIDs , and illustrates diversity within the image dimension .
an urban data framework for assessing equity in city : Comparing accessibility to healthcare facility in Cascadia .
as city continue to grow worldwide , policymaker and urban planner face the dual task of meeting rising demand for essential service while ensuring that benefit accrue to their citizen equitably .
we propose a framework for assessing inclusivity and equity in city , which leverages open data and machine learning technique to inform urban infrastructure investment strategy .
the framework is applied at a regional scale to compare differential access to healthcare facility ( public hospital and clinic ) via public transit in Vancouver , Seattle and Portland .
we find important distributional impact on vulnerable population across the three city .
portland displays the highest inequity in hospital and clinic access , and Vancouver the least , owing to Vancouver 's relatively compact geographic area and high population density .
for senior , over 75 % are socially excluded from hospital and over 50 % from clinic in Portland , compared to 30 % and 3 % respectively in Vancouver .
in all three city , significantly more resident of low-income neighborhood are excluded from healthcare compared to their counterpart in high-income neighborhood .
this translates into proportionally higher transportation cost for low-income area resident compared with high-income area resident , regardless of whether they are socially excluded or not .
transportation cost are notably high for low-income senior in Seattle and Vancouver .

these finding pose a challenge for inclusive planning , since low-income and senior population may require specialized service and are more reliant on public transportation than the average population .

our evaluation framework provides a systematic approach for municipality to account for the distributional effect of transportation and service infrastructure planning , to integrate equity into their decision-making , and to learn from the success and pitfall of each other 's urban policy .
topic modeling to discover the thematic structure and spatial-temporal pattern of building renovation and adaptive reuse in city .
building alteration and redevelopment play a central role in the revitalization of developed city , where the scarcity of available land limits the construction of new building .
the adaptive reuse of existing space reflects the underlying socioeconomic dynamic of the city and can be a leading indicator of economic growth and diversification .
however , the collective understanding of building alteration pattern is constrained by significant barrier to data accessibility and analysis .
we present a data mining and knowledge discovery process for extracting , analyzing , and integrating building permit data for more than 2,500,000 alteration project from seven major U.S. city .

we utilize natural language processing and topic modeling to discover the thematic structure of construction activity from permit description and merge with other urban data to explore the dynamic of urban change .

the knowledge discovery process proceed in three step : ( 1 ) text mining to identify popular word , popularity change , and their co-appearance likelihood ; ( 2 ) topic modeling using latent Dirichlet allocation ( LDA ) ; and ( 3 ) integrating the topic modeling output with building information and ancillary data to discover the spatial , temporal , and thematic pattern of urban redevelopment and regeneration .

the result demonstrate a generalizable approach that can be used to analyze unstructured text data extracted from permit record across varying database structure , permit typology , and local contexts .

our machine learning methodology can assist city to better monitor building alteration activity , analyze spatiotemporal pattern of redevelopment , and more fully understand the economic , social , and environmental implication of change to the urban built environment .
a framework to simplify pre-processing location-based social media big data for sustainable urban planning and management .
over the last decade , 90 % of Big Data has been generated by people living in urban area .
with the advent of Internet of Things ( IoT ) and the increased use of the internet , Social Media has become an integral part of people 's daily live .
million of unstructured data are being sent to the cloud every second , providing opinion practically on any discourse .

this makes microblog such as Twitter , Instagram , WeChat , and Facebook smart instrument for urban planner to harvest ‘ big data ’ on socioeconomic , urban dynamic , transportation , land use , resilience , etc .
this study proposed a framework for social media big data mining and data analytic using Twitter .

it demonstrated the functionality of the framework on a case study using Natural Language Processing and Machine Learning technique like Latent Dirichlet Allocation and VADER Sentiment Analysis to mine , clean , process , and validate the data .
the validated result from the case study showed high accuracy that Social Media Big Data can be used to study the spatiotemporal dynamism of community challenge .
a value of civic voice for smart city : A big data analysis of civic query posed by Seoul citizen .
since urban problem are increasingly becoming complex and multifaceted due to the rapid urbanization , interest in the development of smart city as an efficient solution to such problem is growing .

the significance of smart city lies in not having technology itself but using technology with a novel approach to solve urban problem , enhance the quality of life for urban resident , and optimize government performance .

such an approach includes scientifically processing civic query ( including complaint , suggestion , and inquiry ) data about a city and planning the city such that its policy reflect its resident ' voice to ensure “ throughput legitimacy.
” This study introduces a novel approach to analyze diverse informal civic query data for a city and plan the city in a way that its resident want .

by analyzing 160,000 civic query accumulated over 10 year from 2006 to 2017 from the “ Oasis of 10 Million Imagination , ” which is a civic participation platform of Seoul , this study aims to contribute to the sustainable development of Seoul so that it can plan a citizen-centric and smart city that satisfies the demand of its resident .
by applying Dynamic Topic Model , the author intend to specify civic demand and forecast the demand of citizen .
a data-informed analytical approach to human-scale greenway planning : Integrating multi-sourced urban data with machine learning algorithm .
urban greenway have been recognized as an important strategy to improve human-scale quality in high-density built environment .
nevertheless , current greenway suitability analysis mainly focuses on geographical and natural issue , failing to account for human-scale urban design factor .

accordingly , this study proposes a data-informed approach to planning urban greenway network using a combination of classical urban design theory , multi-sourced urban data , and machine learning algorithms .
maoming City in China was used as a case study .

per classical urban design theory , specifically , Cervero and Ewing 's 5D variable , density , diversity , design , dimension of destination accessibility , and distance-to-transit , were selected as key factor .

a series of new urban data , including point of interest ( PoIs ) , location-based service ( LBS ) positioning data , and street view image , were applied in conjunction with machine learning algorithm and geographical information system ( GIS ) tools to measure these key factor at a human-scale resolution and generate an optimized greenway suitability analysis .
this analytical approach is an attempt to take human-scale concern into account on a city-wide scale regarding greenway network generation .
it also pushes the methodological boundary of greenway planning by combining classical urban design thinking with new urban data and new technique .
unveiling Topic from Scientific Literature on the Subject of Self-driving Cars using Latent Dirichlet Allocation .
self-driving car are becoming popular topic in academia .
consumer of self-driving car and vehicle have different concern , for example , safety and security , to name a few .
also , the public sector has interest in self-driving car such as amending policy to enable the management of self-driving vehicle in city , urban planning , traffic management and , etc .
in this paper , more than 2700 corpus are extracted from literature from several subject area to identify latent ( hidden ) topic of self-driving car .
latent Dirichlet Allocation ( LDA ) is used for topic identification .

the result of this study shows that topic identified are valid research area such as urban planning , driver car ( computer ) interaction , self-driving control and system design , ethic in self-driving car , safety and risk assessment , training dataset quality and machine learning in self-driving car are among the topic identified .

furthermore , the network visualization of association graph of term show that the most frequently discussed concept reveal that control of self-driving car is based on algorithms , data , design , method , and model .
the method used in this study and the result can be used as decision tool , if carefully applied , in diverse discipline that are disrupted by the introduction of self-driving car .
for future study , we plan to extend this study with a larger dataset and other data mining technique .
detecting player personality behavior with any effort of concealment .

we introduce a novel natural language processing component using machine learning technique for prediction of personality behavior of player in a serious game , Land Science , where player act as intern in an urban planning firm and discuss in group their idea about urban planning and environmental science in written natural language .
our model learns vector space representation for various feature extraction .
in order to apply this framework , input excerpt must be classified into one of six possible personality class .
we applied this personality classification task using several machine learning algorithm , such as : Naïve Bayes , Support Vector Machines , and Decision Tree .
training is performed on a relatively dataset of manually annotated excerpt .

by combining these feature space from psychology and computational linguistic , we perform and evaluate our approach to detecting personality , and eventually develop a classifier that is nearly 83 % accurate on our dataset .
based on the feature analysis of our model , we add several theoretical contribution , including revealing a relationship between different personality behavior in player ' writing .
automated detection of mentor and player in an educational game .
automatically identifying the various role ( e.g.
, mentor , player ) in multi-party collaborative chat is a challenging task .
to better understand the conversational demand of mentor and player , this paper investigates the dynamic and linguistic feature of multi-party chat in the context of an online educational game .

in this paper we introduce a novel computational linguistic method using a machine learning algorithm to automatically classify utterance of player and mentor in a serious game , where player act as intern in an urban planning firm and discuss their idea about urban planning and environmental science in written natural language .
our result are promising and our model can be extended to any multi-party environment that Leader ( Mentors ) are needed to be distinguished based on their conversation .
machine learning technology for sustainability in smart city in the post-covid era .
the unprecedented urban growth of recent year requires improved urban planning and management to make urban space more inclusive , safe , resilient and sustainable .
additionally , humanity faces the COVID pandemic , which especially complicates the management of Smart Cities .
a possible solution to address these two problem ( environmental and health ) in Smart Cities may be the use of Machine Learning technique .
one of the objective of our work is to thoroughly analyze the link between the concept of Smart Cities , Machine Learning technique and their applicability .
in this work , an exhaustive study of the relationship between Smart Cities and the applicability of Machine Learning ( ML ) technique is carried out with the aim of optimizing sustainability .
for this , the ML model , analyzed from the point of view of the model , technique and application , are studied .
the area and dimension of sustainability addressed are analyzed , and the Sustainable Development Goals ( SDGs ) are discussed .
the main objective is to propose a model ( EARLY ) that allows us to tackle these problem in the future .
an inclusive perspective on applicability , sustainability scope and dimension , SDGs , tool , data type and Machine Learning technique is provided .
finally , a case study applied to an Andalusian city is presented .
secure blockchain-based traffic load balancing using edge computing and reinforcement learning .
congestion represents one of the major problem in constantly growing city , and the expansion and modernization of the traffic system are a major priority to all government infrastructure .
in effect , more efficient traffic represents a more efficient economy .

solving the issue of congestion by increasing the number of Road is not always the most cost-effective solution as it represents massive change in city infrastructure that have been present for decade .
urban planning shapes the environment around us but fails to address specifically the future traffic clogging .

our research tackles the problem of traffic congestion by proposing a system for vehicle detection , identification , and count , allied with reinforcement learning for traffic congestion anticipation and prediction .
the need for a real-time and efficient system led us to push the research and development onto an Edge Computing platform using IoT and secure transaction using Hyperledger Fabric blockchain .
blockchain intervene as a security protocol in the proposed system .
the native form of Internet of Things does not include security protocol which are important to a large scale implementation .
ensuring the security of transaction and permanent access control is the main reason why blockchain is rooted in our system architecture .

our project aims to reduce the traffic load on Road experiencing significant congestion , and improve overall city traffic system without costly investment into new communication infrastructure and city planning .
online urban-waterlogging monitoring based on a recurrent neural network for classification of microblogging text .
with the global climate change and rapid urbanization , urban flood disaster spread and become increasingly serious in China .
urban rainstorm and waterlogging have become an urgent challenge that needs to be monitored in real time and further predicted for the improvement of urbanization construction .

we trained a recurrent neural network ( RNN ) model to classify microblogging post related to urban waterlogging and establish an online monitoring system of urban waterlogging caused by flood disaster .
we manually curated more than 4400 waterlogging post to train the RNN model so that it can precisely identify waterlogging-related post of Sina Weibo to timely determine urban waterlogging .

the RNN model has been thoroughly evaluated , and our experimental result showed that it achieved higher accuracy than traditional machine learning method , such as the support vector machine ( SVM ) and gradient boosting decision tree ( GBDT ) .
furthermore , we build a nationwide map of urban waterlogging based on recent 2-year microblogging data .
safe city in the new urban world : A comparative cluster dynamic analysis through machine learning .
city in the ‘ New Urban World ’ display an enormous diversity in appearance , growth and performance .
the awareness is growing that the urban development potential ( ‘ magnetism ’ ) of city is closely related to safety and security condition in these city .

this paper develops a new analytical framework based on a wealth of empirical data on both safety/security and socio-economic magnetism achievement of many world city , by combining two comprehensive relevant global urban data base .

the aim of the study is to offer a comparative analysis of the combined safety/security data and socio-economic performance data of 30 global city , through the use of an advanced sequential cluster dynamic analysis that is ( partly ) inspired by a novel machine learning approach ( using Python software ) .
in this way , city can be categorized according to their quantitative characteristic feature represented by the relevant cluster .
it appears that city safety/security feature are an important predictor of the variability in overall urban performance regarding magnetism .
this study allows also for drawing relevant policy lesson .
delineation of an Urban Community Life Circle Based on a Machine-Learning Estimation of Spatiotemporal Behavioral Demand .
delineating life circle is an essential prerequisite for urban community life circle planning .
recent study combined the environmental contexts with resident ’ global positioning system ( GPS ) data to delineate the life circle .
this method , however , is constrained by GPS data , and it can only be applied in the GPS surveyed community .
to address this limitation , this study developed a generalizable delineation method without the constraint of behavioral data .
according to previous research , the community life circle consists of the walking-accessible range and internal structure .

the core task to develop the generalizable method was to estimate the spatiotemporal behavioral demand for each plot of land to acquire the internal structure of the life circle , as the range can be delineated primarily based on environmental data .
therefore , behavioral demand estimation model were established through logistic regression and machine learning technique , including decision tree and ensemble learning .
the model with the lowest error rate was chosen as the final estimation model for each type of land .
finally , we used a community without GPS data as an example to demonstrate the effectiveness of the estimation model and delineation method .

this article extends the existing literature by introducing spatiotemporal behavioral demand estimation model , which learn the relationship between environmental contexts , population composition and the existing delineated result based on GPS data to delineate the internal structure of the community life circle without employing behavioral data .

furthermore , the proposed method and delineation result also contributes to facility adjustment and location selection in life circle planning , people-oriented transformation in urban planning , and activity space estimation of the population in evaluating and improving the urban policy .
applying machine learning and geolocation technique to social media data ( Twitter ) to develop a resource for urban planning .
with all the recent attention focused on big data , it is easy to overlook that basic vital statistic remain difficult to obtain in most of the world .

what makes this frustrating is that private companie hold potentially useful data , but it is not accessible by the people who can use it to track poverty , reduce disease , or build urban infrastructure .
this project set out to test whether we can transform an openly available dataset ( Twitter ) into a resource for urban planning and development .

we test our hypothesis by creating road traffic crash location data , which is scarce in most resource-poor environment but essential for addressing the number one cause of mortality for children over five and young adult .

the research project scraped 874,588 traffic related tweet in Nairobi , Kenya , applied a machine learning model to capture the occurrence of a crash , and developed an improved geoparsing algorithm to identify its location .
we geolocate 32,991 crash report in Twitter for 2012-2020 and cluster them into 22,872 unique crash during this period .
for a subset of crash reported on Twitter , a motorcycle delivery service was dispatched in real-time to verify the crash and its location ; the result show 92 % accuracy .
to our knowledge this is the first geolocated dataset of crash for the city and allowed us to produce the first crash map for Nairobi .
using a spatial clustering algorithm , we are able to locate portion of the road network ( < 1 % ) where 50 % of the crash identified occurred .

even with limitation in the representativeness of the data , the result can provide urban planner with useful information that can be used to target road safety improvement where resource are limited .
the work shows how twitter data might be used to create other type of essential data for urban planning in resource poor environment .
opportunity and challenge of geospatial analysis for promoting urban livability in the era of big data and machine learning .
urban system involve a multitude of closely intertwined component , which are more measurable than before due to new sensor , data collection , and spatio-temporal analysis method .

turning these data into knowledge to facilitate planning effort in addressing current challenge of urban complex system requires advanced interdisciplinary analysis method , such as urban informatic or urban data science .

yet , by applying a purely data-driven approach , it is too easy to get lost in the ‘ forest ’ of data , and to miss the ‘ tree ’ of successful , livable city that are the ultimate aim of urban planning .

this paper assesses how geospatial data , and urban analysis , using a mixed method approach , can help to better understand urban dynamic and human behavior , and how it can assist planning effort to improve livability .

based on reviewing state-of-the-art research the paper goes one step further and also addresses the potential as well as limitation of new data source in urban analytic to get a better overview of the whole ‘ forest ’ of these new data source and analysis method .

the main discussion revolves around the reliability of using big data from social media platform or sensor , and how information can be extracted from massive amount of data through novel analysis method , such as machine learning , for better-informed decision making aiming at urban livability improvement .
exploring the relationship between ride-sourcing service and vehicle ownership , using both inferential and machine learning approach .
ride-sourcing service are getting more popular each year , and their market are growing .
much has been speculated , but not much has been tested regarding the impact of ride-sourcing service on the transportation system .
in this study , we examine the relationship between ride-sourcing service and vehicle ownership of household , by using the most up-to-date ( 2017 ) national household travel survey data .
to better capture the effect of ride-sourcing service on vehicle ownership , we controlled for the effect of socioeconomic characteristic of household and built environment variable , i.e.
, density , diversity , design , and distance to transit .
two approach were used to model vehicle ownership : a probabilistic or inferential model ( i.e.
, multilevel Poisson ) , and a machine learning method ( i.e.
, random forest ) .

this is the first study to utilize such advanced method to model vehicle ownership and capture non-linear relationship , using the largest sample of household travel record ever assembled for such a study .
the result suggest that there is a negative correlation between using ride-sourcing service and vehicle ownership .
vehicle ownership is also negatively associated with the number of year Uber , as the biggest ride-sourcing service , has operated in a county .
the relative contribution of ride-sourcing variable , however , are very limited compared to other variable controlled in this study which makes intuitive sense .

for urban planning and design practice , this study suggests that the probability of car shedding will increase if the usage of ride-sourcing service becomes a habit , these service become more available , and built environment become more dense , connected , and transit-served .
combining design pattern and topic modeling to discover region that support particular functionality .

the problem of discovering region that support particular functionality in an urban setting has been approached in literature using two general methodology : top-down , encoding expert knowledge on urban planning and design and discovering region that conform to that knowledge ; and bottom-up , using data to train machine learning model , which can discover similar region .

both methodology face limitation , with knowledge-based approach being criticized for scalability and transferability issue and data-driven approach for lacking interpretability and depending heavily on data quality .

to mitigate these disadvantage , we propose a novel framework that fuses a knowledge-based approach using design pattern and a data-driven approach using latent Dirichlet allocation ( LDA ) topic modeling in three different way : Functional region discovered using either approach are evaluated against each other to identify case of significant agreement or disagreement ; knowledge from pattern is used to adjust topic probability in the learning model ; and topic probability are used to adjust pattern-based result .
the proposed methodology are demonstrated through the use case of identifying shopping-related region in the Los Angeles metropolitan area .

result show that the combination of pattern-based discovery and topic modeling extraction helps uncover discrepancy between the two approach and smooth inaccuracy caused by the limitation of each approach .
crowdsensed Data Learning-Driven Prediction of Local Businesses Attractiveness in Smart Cities .
urban planning typically relies on experience-based solution and traditional methodology to face urbanization issue and investigate the complex dynamic of city .
recently , novel data-driven approach in urban computing have emerged for researcher and companie .
they aim to address historical urbanization issue by exploiting sensing data gathered by mobile device under the so-called mobile crowdsensing ( MCS ) paradigm .
this work shows how to exploit sensing data to improve traditionally experience-based approach for urban decision .
in particular , we apply widely known Machine Learning ( ML ) technique to achieve highly accurate result in predicting category of local business ( LBs ) ( e.g.
, bar , restaurant ) , and their attractiveness in term of class of temporal demand ( e.g.
, nightlife , business hour ) .
the performance evaluation is conducted in Luxembourg city and the city of Munich with publicly available crowdsensed dataset .
the result highlight that our approach does not only achieve high accuracy , but it also unveils important hidden feature of the interaction of citizen and LBs .
uncovering the relationship between point-of-interests-related human mobility and socioeconomic status .
in a city or region , understanding the relationship between human mobility and socioeconomic status is critical to public policy formulation , urban design and marketing strategy development .
based on the available massive geo-located human data , existing study focused almost exclusively on the position attributes ( i.e .
coordinate ) of the location visited by people to explore the relationship , however , they ignored the category attributes ( e.g .
restaurant or supermarket ) of these location which imply the purpose ( e.g .
eating or shopping ) behind human movement .
a location with coordinate and category information is usually referred to as a point-of-interest ( POI ) .
in this paper , we study the relationship between POIs-related human mobility and socioeconomic status at city level .
starting from the location-based social network ( i.e .
foursquare ) dataset , we find that the check-in number of location category are correlated with socioeconomic indicator , either positively or negatively .
to further validate these correlation , we develop and test a multi-task prediction framework based on POIs-related human mobility for forecasting socioeconomic indicator .
extensive experiment on the Foursquare dataset show that the socioeconomic indicator can be well predicted by our proposed framework .
our finding and method are helpful for modeling human mobility and assessing socioeconomic status .
mining heterogeneous urban data for retail store placement .
retail store placement problem has been extensively studied in both academic and industry as it decides the retail success of a business .
existing method exploited either consumer study ( e.g.
, consultant-based solution ) or geographic feature ( e.g.
, point of interest ) to settle it .
however , due to the limitation of data source ( i.e.
, costly in time and labor ) , none of these method could provide an accurate and timely solution .
in this paper , we rethink retail store placement problem by mining heterogeneous urban data .
in particular , unlike existing work which only used geographic feature or consumer study solely , we extract three category of feature ( i.e.

, human movement feature , commercial area feature and geographic feature ) from heterogeneous urban data , and integrate them into various machine learning model to predict the popularity of a prospective retail store in the candidate area .
we conduct a case study with real data in Shenzhen to demonstrate the predictive power of our proposal .
learning task-specific city region partition .
the proliferation of publicly accessible urban data provide new insight on various urban task .
a frequently used approach is to treat each region as a data sample and build a model over all the region to observe the correlation between urban feature ( e.g.
, demographic ) and the target variable ( e.g.
, crime count ) .
to define region , most existing study use fixed grid or pre-defined administrative boundary ( e.g.
, census tract or community area ) .
in reality , however , definition of region should be different depending on task ( e.g.
, regional crime count prediction vs. real estate price estimation ) .
in this paper , we propose a new problem of task-specific city region partitioning , aiming to find the best partition in a city w.r.t .
a given task .
we prove this is an NP-hard search problem with no trivial solution .
to learn the partition , we first study two variant of Markov Chain Monte Carlo ( MCMC ) .
we further propose a reinforcement learning scheme for effective sampling the search space .
we conduct experiment on two real dataset in Chicago ( i.e.
, crime count and real estate price ) to demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed method .
can we predict the scenic beauty of location from geo-tagged Flickr image ?
in this work , we propose a novel technique to determine the aesthetic score of a location from social metadata of Flickr photo .
in particular , we built machine learning classifier to predict the class of a location where each class corresponds to a set of location having equal aesthetic rating .
these model are trained on two empirically build dataset containing location in two different city ( Rome and Paris ) where aesthetic rating of location were gathered from TripAdvisor.com .
in this work we exploit the idea that in a location with higher aesthetic rating , it is more likely for an user to capture a photo and other user are more likely to interact with that photo .
our model achieved as high as 79.48 % accuracy ( 78.60 % precision and 79.27 % recall ) on Rome dataset and 73.78 % accuracy ( 75.62 % precision and 78.07 % recall ) on Paris dataset .
the proposed technique can facilitate urban planning , tour planning and recommending aesthetically pleasing path .
robust anomaly detection in urban environment using sensor and information fusion and a camera network .
the paper presents a method for detection of abnormal behavior related to violent event in urban environment .
we have further developed a person detection method and introduced a person tracker as an intermediate stage between person detection and anomaly detection .
the method is presented together with result from evaluation based on real sensor data that have been recorded in a realistic urban environment .
several scenario have been recorded such as normal situation , a person loitering , a person shooting and people escaping from sudden smoke development .
the method uses sensor data from a static video surveillance system , consisting of two visual and two thermal infrared camera .
the person detection method combine foreground segmentation with a trained machine learning algorithm which is based on boosting .
the tracker associates incoming detection to object ( i.e .
people ) , and generates track of world coordinate and velocity of object .
the anomaly detection method , which is based on the hidden Markov model ( HMM ) , fuses information that is derived from the tracker .
the information contains a number of person , their position and velocity .

the result indicate that the person detection method in combination with the tracker can produce robust and accurate observation to the HMM , which in turn provide good condition for accurate anomaly detection .
data mining technique for smart mobility—a survey .
with the rapid increase in urbanization , there is essence for making urban area smart .
there are assorted Field of computer science liable for development of a city to make it smart and intelligent .
some of these Field include data mining , sensor network , Internet of thing , web of thing , cloud computing technique and machine learning .
smart city is an umbrella term that encompasses smart mobility , smart governance , smart planning , smart environment and other .
smart mobility is one of the crucial aspect of smart city addressing efficient movement of people and good from one place to another .
this work is an extensive survey of research work related to application of data mining technique for smart mobility .
a comparative study of major work done in the aforementioned field is outlined in this paper .
multiscale spatio-temporal data aggregation and mapping for urban data exploration .
map seem the most intuitive way to visualize massive urban data but they also raise some well-known graphical problem ( such as visual clutter , etc . )
this paper focuses on processing massive spatiotemporal data in order to ease multi-scale exploration .

to this end , we describe a preprocessing tool that enables the automatic creation of a multi-resolution grid from a high resolution grid of spatio-temporal data in a format compatible with webmapping application ( vector tile ) .
the use of this tool is exemplified through a prototype that offers the possibility to navigate into a massive itinerary request dataset collected in the Ile-de- France region .
urban computing and smart city : Opportunitie and challenge in modelling large-scale aggregated human behavior .
city-wide urban infrastructure are increasingly reliant on networked technology to improve and expand their service .

as a side effect of this digitalization , large amount of data -digital footprints- can be sensed and analyzed to uncover pattern of human urban behavior and to augment the city experience of its citizen .

in my talk , I will introduce the main concept , opportunity and challenge in the emerging area of urban computing/smart city , which focuses on improving the quality of life of an urban environment by understanding the city dynamic through the data provided by ubiquitous technology .
this is a human-centric , data-rich area that spans multiple discipline , including sociology , computer science and urban planning .

from a computer science perspective , there are challenge in a variety of domain , including data visualization , storage , security , privacy , machine learning , data mining and pattern recognition .
some of the application of smart city include traffic forecasting , modeling of the spread of biological virus , urban and transportation design and location-based service .
street context of various demographic group in their daily mobility .

we present an urban science framework to characterize phone user ’ exposure to different street context type based on network science , geographical information system ( GIS ) , daily individual trajectory , and street imagery .
we consider street context as the inferred usage of the street , based on its building and construction , categorized in nine possible label .
the label define whether the street is residential , commercial or downtown , throughway or not , and other special category .
we apply the analysis to the City of Boston , considering daily trajectory synthetically generated with a model based on call detail record ( CDR ) and image from Google Street View .
image are categorized both manually and using artificial intelligence ( AI ) .

we focus on the city ’ s four main racial/ethnic demographic group ( White , Black , Hispanic and Asian ) , aiming to characterize the difference in what these group of people see during their daily activity .
based on daily trajectory , we reconstruct most common path over the street network .
we use street demand ( number of time a street is included in a trajectory ) to detect each group ’ s most relevant Street and region .
based on their street demand , we measure the street context distribution for each group .
the inclusion of image allows us to quantitatively measure the prevalence of each context and point to qualitative difference on where that context takes place .
other AI methodology can further exploit these difference .
this approach presents the building block to further study that relate mobile device ’ dynamic record with the difference in urban exposure by demographic group .

the addition of AI-based image analysis to street demand can power up the capability of urban planning methodology , compare multiple city under a unified framework , and reduce the crudeness of GIS-only mobility analysis .

shortening the gap between big data-driven analysis and traditional human classification analysis can help build smarter and more equal city while reducing the effort necessary to study a city ’ s characteristic .
smart environment design planning for smart city based on deep learning .

machine Learning ( ML ) and Deep Learning ( DL ) method have contributed to the progression of model in the different aspect of planning , prediction , and uncertainty analysis of urban and smart city development in the current scenario .
most developed city have suffered from severe air quality as population growth and industrialization grow rapidly .
government agency and citizen are increasingly concerned about air quality , which has an impact on various area of the human environment and human advancement .

conventional method of air pollution forecasting primarily use low-level simulation , and these model generate disappointing result that have led us to factor that influence air pollution measurement based on a thorough design of the structure .

furthermore , in this paper , Long Short- Term Memory ( LSTM ) assisted Staked Auto-Encoder ( SAE ) ( LSTM-SAE ) model has been proposed for predicting the air quality in smart environment design planning in the smart city .
long Short- Term Memory is used to evaluate air pollution quality prediction in smart city .
staked Auto-Encoder ( SAE ) is modeled and prepared gently to extract the intrinsic component that occur due to air pollution .

furthermore , the finding indicate that classification accuracy of 91.22 % and the overall Error rate of 0.46 has been validated , and LSTM-SAE addresses the different aspect of smart city and effective method when compared to other existing method .
dtex : A dynamic urban thermal exposure index based on human mobility pattern .
background : Extreme heat in light of climate change is increasingly threatening the health and comfort of urban resident .
understanding spatio-temporal pattern of heat exposure is a critical factor in directing mitigation measure .

current heat vulnerability indice provide insight into heat sensitivity within given community but do not account for the dynamic nature of the human movement as people travel for different activity .
here , we present a new Dynamic urban Thermal Exposure index ( DTEx ) that captures the varying heat exposure within urban environment .
method : We developed the DTEx to understand human heat exposure patterns in a mid-sized city .
this index incorporates the human movement pattern and the heat hazard pattern obtained via novel and advanced technique .
we generated the human movement pattern from large-scale , anonymized smartphone location data .
the heat hazard pattern were extrapolated via machine learning model from air temperature data measured through vehicle-mounted sensor .
the exposure index was then developed by combining the two parameter using their standard-deviation-classified indice .
result : Our exposure index varied between 2 and 12 , indicating low to high thermal exposure .
several high-temperature spot associated with a large volume of foot traffic are successfully identified through this DTEx .
we observed the hottest spot at shopping plazas but not specifically in the urban center .
during the selected football gameday , the exposure index surged across most Place near the football stadium but was reduced considerably further away .
discussion : The proposed DTEx is novel because it provides dynamic heat monitoring capability to facilitate heat mitigation strategy at vulnerable location in urban environment .
combining the mobility data and extensive sensor data generate rich detail on the most heat-exposed area due to human congregation .
such information will be critical for risk communication and urban planning for policymaker .
dtex could also help smart route planning in sustainable city to avoid heat hazard risk .
a data-driven agent-based simulation to predict crime pattern in an urban environment .
spatial crime simulation contribute to our understanding of the mechanism that drive crime and can support decision-maker in developing effective crime reduction strategy .
agent-based model that integrate geographical environment to generate crime pattern have emerged in recent year , although data-driven crime simulation are scarce .

this article ( 1 ) identifie numerous important driver of crime pattern , ( 2 ) collect relevant , openly available data source to build a GIS-layer with static and dynamic geographical , as well as temporal feature relevant to crime , ( 3 ) builds a virtual urban environment with these layer , in which individual offender agent navigate , ( 4 ) proposes a data-driven decision-making process using machine-learning for the agent to decide whether to engage in criminal activity based on their perception of the environment and , finally , ( 5 ) generates fine-grained crime pattern in a simulated urban environment .

the novelty of this work lies in the various large-scale data layer , the integration of machine learning at individual agent level to process the data layer , and the high resolution of the resulting prediction .
the result show that the spatial , temporal , and interaction layer are all required to predict the top street segment with the highest number of crime .
in addition , the spatial layer is the most informative , which means that spatial data contributes most to predictive performance .
thus , these finding highlight the importance of the inclusion of various open data source and the potential of theory-informed , data-driven simulation for the purpose of crime prediction .
the resulting model is applicable as a predictive tool and as a test platform to support crime reduction .
interpretation of contextual influence with explanatory tool : Travel mode likelihood mapping using GPS trajectory .
past study have failed to address the spatially and temporally varying impact of environmental factor regarding the uncertain geographic context problem .

this study seeks to provide an innovative framework to facilitate the understanding of spatially and temporally varying impact of multiple contexts on individual ' travel mode using GIS and machine learning technique .

it adopts machine learning technique to create likelihood map to predict the spatiotemporal pattern of individual travel behavior and uses explanatory tool to explore the spatially and temporally varying impact .
the most notable change at a local level in the spatial dimension was that assault and offenses involving children turned out to be important in two selected community in Chicago .

regarding the temporally varying impact , battery , other offense , and robbery showed negative association with the walking prediction to some extent at the afternoon peak ( 5–7:59 p.m. ) during weekday .

the proposed approach will enable meaningful interpretation of complex interaction between multiple environmental factor and individual travel behavior to suggest policy in urban planning and design .
chain store placement recommendation with multi-source urban data .
with the rapid development of chain store , how to recommend the placement of new store becomes a challenge .
existing work mainly focus on using feature-based model to recommend Place for store .
different from existing work , we focus on the scale-based store placement problem , which can not recommend Place for a store , but also suggest the right scale for the store .
firstly , we extract geospatial feature , business feature and scale-relevant feature to characterize the urban region .
secondly , we present regression and classification method for dealing with two situation : recommending Place with a given scale , and recommending scale given the place .
experiment over real world dataset prove the effectiveness of our method .
identifying spatio-temporal hotspot of human activity that are popular non-work destination .

the improved temporal and spatial granularity of data now available from current information technology offers an opportunity to study previously unexplored dimension of the relationship between built environment and social outcome .

within the field of urban study , an old question worth revisiting with these new technology is how to best trace the spatial boundary that circumscribe a place or location to explore non-work activity .
in this study , we explore a data-driven definition of Place as unit of analysis that can be used to explore non-work activity in Singapore .
such a definition of place characterizes an urban space in term of its concentration of activity and the topology of the built environment–features that are especially important to urban planner .
we utilize available smartphone data to develop a systematic framework to identify location with a concentrated human presence .

using a cylinder moving over a grid representing Singapore , we scan aggregated smartphone locational request ( by time and cell ) , identifying area with atypical high concentration at a given time .
our tool identified 93 Place with a concentrated human presence .

direct observation of six of these Place at the selected time in conjunction with additional transportation and population data indicated that the topology of commercial establishment provided a strong approximation of non-work activity at a given time and place .

having established the relevance of commercial establishment in approximating non-work activity , then points-of-interest data within the 93 derived Place are used to propose a typology of commercial patch , based on their spatial configuration .
nine metric of the geometry and topology of patch of establishment , such as compacity and their dependence on proximity to shopping mall , were developed .
these combined variable revealed more temporal and spatial variety within location than had previously been recognized .
the most popular Place for non-work activity were densely configured with various commercial sub-space or patch appealing to different lifestyle and income group .

this study suggests that a location/place can be best defined as a highly detailed , multi-faceted , and always evolving area of activity rather than as a fixed location with temporal and unmovable boundary .
suggesting a dynamic redefinition of location/place that builds on other recent work , this work offers potential contribution to locational model for non-work activity .
an Intelligent Tree Planning Approach Using Location-Based Social Networks Data .
how do we make sure that all citizen in a city have access to enough green space ?
an increasing part of the world ’ s population live in urban area , where contact with nature is largely reduced to street tree and park .
as optional tree planting site and financial resource are limited , determining the best planting site can be formulated as an optimization problem with constraint .
can we locate these site based on the popularity of nearby venue ?
how can we ensure that we include group of people who tend to spend time in tree deprived area ?
currently , tree location site are chosen based on criterion from spatial-visual , physical and biological , and functional category .

as these criterion do not give any insight into which citizen are benefiting from the tree placement , we propose new data-driven tree planting policy that take socio-cultural aspect as represented by the citizen ’ behavior into account .
we combine a Location Based Social Network ( LBSN ) mobility data set with tree location data set , both of New York City and Paris , as a case study .
the effect of four different policy is evaluated on simulated movement data and assessed on the average , overall exposure to tree as well as on how much inequality in tree exposure is mitigated .
introduction to Urban Computing .
this chapter overviews Part V of this book themed urban computing .

this part of the book covers the topic of visual analytic , cloud , edge , and mobile computing , data mining and knowledge discovery , AI and deep learning for urban computing , and a range of mainstream urban model and simulation method .
it provides a systematic review of computing technology for urban governance and urban service , together with the example of their usage , in the context of urban computing .
ai and Deep Learning for Urban Computing .

in the big data era , with the large volume of available data collected by various sensor deployed in urban area and the recent advance in AI technique , urban computing has become increasingly important to facilitate the improvement of people ’ s live , city operation system , and the environment .
in this chapter , we introduce the challenge , methodology , and application of AI technique for urban computing .
we first introduce the background , followed by listing key challenge from the perspective of computer science when AI technique are applied .

then we briefly introduce the AI technique that are widely used in urban computing , including supervised learning , semi-supervised learning , unsupervised learning , matrix factorization , graphic model , deep learning , and reinforcement learning .
with the recent advance of deep-learning technique , model such as CNN and RNN have shown significant performance gain in many application .
thus , we briefly introduce the deep-learning model that are widely used in various urban-computing task .

finally , we discuss the application of urban computing including urban planning , urban transportation , location-based social network ( LBSNs ) , urban safety and security , and urban-environment monitoring .
for each application , we summarize major research challenge and review previous work that uses AI technique to address them .
predicting and mapping neighborhood-scale health outcome : A machine learning approach .
estimating health outcome at a neighborhood scale is important for promoting urban health , yet costly and time-consuming .
in this paper , we present a machine-learning-enabled approach to predicting the prevalence of six common non-communicable chronic disease at the census tract level .
we apply our approach to the City of Austin and show that our method can yield fairly accurate prediction .

in searching for the best predictive model , we experiment with eight different machine learning algorithms and 60 predictor variable that characterize the social environment , the physical environment , and the aspect and degree of neighborhood disorder .

our analysis suggests that ( a ) the sociodemographic and socioeconomic variable are the strongest predictor for tract-level health outcome and ( b ) the historical record of 311 service request can be a useful complementary data source as the information distilled from the 311 data often helps improve the model ' performance .

the machine learning model yielded from this study can help the public and city official evaluate future scenario and understand how change in the neighborhood condition can lead to change in the health outcome .

by analyzing where the most significant discrepancy between the predicted and the actual value are , we will also be ready to identify area of best practice and area in need of greater investment or policy intervention .
harnessing Social Interactions on Twitter for Smart Transportation Using Machine Learning .
twitter is generating a large amount of real-time data in the form of microblog that has potential knowledge for various application like traffic incident analysis and urban planning .
social media data represents the unbiased actual insight of citizen ’ concern that may be mined in making city smarter .
in this study , a computational framework has been proposed using word embedding and machine learning model to detect traffic incident using social media data .

the study includes the feasibility of using machine learning algorithms with different feature extraction and representation model for the identification of traffic incident from the Twitter interaction .
the comprehensive proposed approach is the combination of following four step .
in the first phase , a dictionary of traffic-related keyword is formed .
secondly , real-time Twitter data has been collected using the dictionary of identified traffic related keyword .
in the third step , collected tweet have been pre-processed , and the feature generation model is applied to convert the dataset eligible for a machine learning classifier .
further , a machine learning model is trained and tested to identify the tweet containing traffic incident .
the result of the study show that machine learning model built on top of right feature extraction strategy is very promising to identify the tweet containing traffic incident from micro-blog .

ballparking the Urban placeness : A case study of analyzing starbuck post on instagram .
placeness or the “ sense of a place ” plays a vital role in urban design and planning .
research on placeness in the past has been conducted via conventional method like survey to reveal essential insight for urban planner and architect .

for taking a glimpse into placeness by analyzing common factor across geography , we choose Instagram post from Starbucks as a case study , owing to its the-next-door coffee shop psychological construct .
we conduct our research by first adopting a flexible ontological framework to organize the concept governing placeness .
next , we curate a dataset of community generated Instagram post from Starbucks in three major metropolitan city of the world : New York , Seoul , and Tokyo .
the curated dataset is then automatically enriched with contextual attribute such as activity , visitor demographic , and time via machine learning technique .
we finally analyze and validate the quantitative variation in contextual information with finding from well-accepted cross-cultural case study .
our result show that placeness mined from Starbucks , a prominent urban third-place , can be reliably utilized to discover surrounding urban placeness .
investigating Customer Satisfaction Patterns in a Community Livability Context : An Efficiency-Oriented Decision-Making Approach .

a comprehensive understanding of neighborhood facility distribution and function along with residential quality of life satisfaction is a key asset for relating livability management to transportation network .
due to the simultaneous involvement of varied factor with an individual 's perception of livability , this concept is difficult to measure .
therefore , a more objective mean of quantifying livability is needed .

the service industry has demonstrated the intersection of machine learning classifier and survey domain knowledge for evaluating user ' quality of experience ; however , this process of inquiry-based learning has never been considered for solving the communication difficulty between community stakeholder and transportation agency .

another area of overlap is that of urban computing , which integrates computing technology in the traditional context of urban area , connecting ubiquitous sensing technology , computational power , and data about the urban environment to promote quality of life for people living in a particular community .

to this aim , the focus of this study is on interpreting a linkage between society stated preference and quantitative measure of livability by extracting information from survey-based method and translating it to a quantitative framework using combined service industry and urban computing methodology .

this work focuses on four transportation planning-related research question in this blended framework : understanding existing livability pattern , predicting heterogeneous perception of quality of life , prioritizing public preference , and developing a multidimensional livability index ( MLI ) .

processing , mining and visualizing massive urban data .
the development of smart technology and the advent of new observation capability have increased the availability of massive urban dataset that can greatly benefit urban study .

for example , a large amount of urban data is collected by various sensor , such as smart meter , or provided by GSM , Wi-Fi or Bluetooth record , ticketing data , geo- tagged post on social network , etc .

analysis of such digital record can help to build decision-making tool ( for analytical , forecasting and display purpose ) with a view to better understanding the operating of urban system , to enable urban stakeholder to plan better when extending infrastructure and to provide better service to citizen in order to assist the development of the city and improve quality of life .
this paper will focus on three main domain of application : Transportation and mobility , water and energy .

sta : A spatio-temporal thematic analytic framework for urban ground sensing .
urban planning has always involved getting feedback from various stakeholder and member of public , to inform plan and evaluation of proposal .
a lot of rich information comes in textual form , which traditionally have to be read manually .
with advancement in machine learning capability , there is potential to tap on it to aid planner in synthesizing insight from large amount of textual feedback data more efficiently .
in this paper , we developed a more general urban-centric feedback analysis framework , which encompasses the spatio-temporal thematic of ground sensing .
three essential method : geotagging , topic modeling , and trend analysis are proposed and a prototype has been implemented .

the result of experiment indicate that the proposed framework could not only accurately extract precise geospatial information , but also efficiently analyze the semantic theme based on a probabilistic topic modeling with Latent Dirichlet Allocation .

importantly , the spatial and temporal trend of detected topic indicate the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm and then benefit domain expert in their routine work and reveal many interesting insight on ground sensing matter .
